title: How many U.S. states will have an infection rate of 1.0 or greater for COVID-19 as of 31 March 2021?
preds: Small chance it'll be 28 or lower but best bet is 29 or more because I have no evidence what can make it decrease. There are several states at 0.99 or 0.98 which has been part of the increasing trend in the last couple of weeks. Good job, forecasters. Observe and adjust we did, now we watch.
TO MANY 'RED'  STATES IN THE MIX
Very close to the deadline - current data
After reviewing today's data for the states I have to conclude that the chances of the answer falling below 29 are very small.  So I'll join the crowd, all in for "29 or more."

Even though there is only one day left I don't feel I can raise my certainty. There are 32 states with an infection rate of over 29, but the infection rates tend to plato on Wednesdays. Only 5 states need to drop and with many at 1.02 to the 1.03 rang it could happen. because of that, I will be lowering my certainty. this might be a mistake, but anything over 90% feels just too high

There is a weekly pattern for these numbers.  The peak occurs on Sunday and the valley on Wednesday.  The cycle is superimposed on the trend, which of late has been up.  From this pattern I predict the number will go down tomorrow, but probably not below 29.  But it could happen, so I'll put the odds at 71% for "29 or more," which is way below the crowd (100%).  The crowd is probably right, but I don't think it's a done deal.
Wow. I had not updated this since Feb 26, there were 7 states back then with infection rates greater than 1.0, that numbers is 31 today.

There are currently 35 states that have an infection rate of 1.0 of higher.  With only 2 days left in this forecast, chances are highly likely that there will be 29 or more states with this infection rate or greater.

As of now, 35 states have an infection rate of over 1, and many other states hover very close to the margin with 0.97 or above. Due to these numbers, it is almost certain that more than 29 states will have an infection rate over 1 unless a drastic drop occurs in multiple states which is nearly impossible.

Right now around 35 states have an infection rate of 1 or greater and given that March 31 is only 3 days, the infection rate is unlikely to change that much. It seems very likely that the infection rate will be greater than 1 in 29 or more states on March 31.

34 states are above 1.00 right now. B.1.1.7 is starting to kick in in more states and will push Rt over 1. While a few states at the margin may flip, I think it's extremely likely that more will flip up over 1 than down below 1.

There are currently 32 states that have an infection rate greater than 1.0.  The next few days should be based upon higher numbers from last week, so we anticipate a few states dropping off of that amount.

If you actually click on the states just below 1.0 in terms of infection rate, a great number of them are projected to cross into 1.0+ territory. Additionally, a number of states are remaining stagnant or declining in the number of tests per 100k people, which is clearly linked to a rise in cases and also positivity rates (ironically). Currently, cases ARE indeed on the rise, thus I expect less testing at least in the next week. https://covidactnow.org/
https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/testing/tracker/overview

We're already at last bin but because it goes up and down a lot, even stays the same for a day or two, I cannot say 90% or more. Only takes a decline in 9 states to get back to third bin. It jumped up more than 7 or 8 in a day previously.
Boy did I get this one wrong. I know the mainstream narrative is new strains, but possibly the fringe accusation that the experimental vaccines increase transmission is correct.
With how much time has passed in the pandemic, people are growing tiresome of masks and guidlines, so I think that people are going to be less cautious about covid rules.

It is already 29 as of last count, and several midwestern states, including Indiana, Oregon, and Ohio are on the cusp. That being said, there are still a few days left, and the vaccination drive is starting to really kick in. Puerto Rico and a couple other states seem poised to drop below 1.

There are 24 states currently with a week to go.  Prior to this week, the rates have been fairly consistent around 18 states.  With a slight uptick in cases this week, the infection rates should go down a bit next week.
Many states surrounding michigan are hovering right below 1, and that might change rapidly. Already the situation in northern Indiana and Ohio is worsening.

I was more accurate for this question in January [1] than any time afterwards as I lost my nerves even when the trend was moving exactly as I predicted. Learnt my lesson, "being right is not enough, have conviction too" [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1222142
I just counted 24 I think.  I think things are going to get a little worse yet before we see some real improvement in the summer with more vaccinations and outdoor events.
Infection rates have drastically upticked since my last prediction, likely due to continued relaxation of COVID procedures.

Against all expectations, the number of states with Infection Rate equal or more than 1.0 has been going up recently It is now 22 (23 - Puerto Rico). is it because of more transmissible mutations, better screening? Hard to know at this point.
What can we do? Just follow the trend - it is just 1 week left...

A large number of states in the midwest that have infection rates of <1 appear to be at an inflection point. This is likely due to a mixture of the warmer weather and new variants. It appears unlikely that vaccinations would make enough of a difference in the short term.
18 at the moment. I should admit - COVID-19 questions screwed up my score immensely. This question will just add to that.
Racing to stay ahead of Brazil.  After all, We're Number One!
We're up from 18 to 22 in one day.  It looks like to B.117 variant is doing a number on us.  Moving up the ladder.
There are currently 18 states with infection rates over 1.0.  With the new case rates remaining consistent over the past month, this trend is expected to continue.

It looks as if NV, MD, VT, and Mo will drop off before 3/30.  However, CT & WV might break 1. 
We're sitting at 13 that would drop us to 11.  Cut my losses. https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/data/new-cases-50-states
Texas, Mississippi, Iowa, Montana, North Dakota lowered mask mandates as of 3/14
There are 17 states meeting this metric today. Shifting my numbers back up. Kicking myself for letting the crowd talk me down on previous forecasts.

There are 17 states currently, but this number has fluctuated between a couple of states and this high number.  As the COVID numbers decrease, it is more likely that a higher number of states will be over 1.0 just based on the definition of infection rate.

The number of states are rising despite the declining graph of COVID cases. Therefore, I think more weight should be on the relaxing of safety measures such as quarantine mandates, social distancing, mask wearing, etc. The rational thing to do here is to keep the eggs scattered among the brackets. With more states relaxing, I think it is more likely to have 29 or more than 7 or fewer, especially with the end of March looming near. It seems the rise is becoming a trend, not a fad. I may tighten my spread if I see the number of states drop fewer.

What I found with COVID-19 questions is that there are many moving parts that can screw up your forecasts. E.g,. this question. Seems the rate should be going down as we are closer and closer to herd immunity. But economy and politics  are more pronounced: as we are testing and diagnosing only a portion of COVID-19 infections, the number of infected (and "infection rate") can go up just because we test more or catch more exposed subpopulation, even if the real transmission rate goes down. Etc. etc. Frustrating... What can we do? Just "follow the market"...

At 18 now. With national cases pretty flat it's too easy for states to fluctuate around 1.0 to make a confident prediction in the direction. I think the national trend continues downward, but slower, and that means infection rates could fluctuate above one in many states.
15 currently. I do not believe that vaccinations will be able to bring this number below 8.

Yikes, now we're up to 15.  Progress against the virus has stopped, if not reversed in many states.  As a society we have reverted to normal behavior in too many places.  But vaccine doses haven't yet conferred enough immunity to keep case numbers on the decline.  There doesn't seem to be enough time for increased vaccinations to turn things around before the end of March.  It's time to play defense.
As of today, 10 U.S states have an infection rate higher than 1, so I would assume it would fluctuate in the 8-14 range within the next few weeks if at all.
As I discussed before, the reduced infections are creating a smaller base from which this metric is determined. There are 11 states above 1.0 today. I'm shifting the odds back up a bit.
Infection rates have jumped above 1 in 11 states. Vaccinations and a flattening curve should bring these numbers back down, but incorporating this new data in my prediction.

9 currently. -15 on 7 or fewer, +15 on 8 to 14. As cases flatten out the infection rate can easily fluctuate above and below 1.0 in many places. Remains to be seen if we see more decline in cases this month or if we'll stay level or fluctuating up and down.

We've just gone from 6 states to 9.  Three are at 1.00, and another three are just below the cutoff, at 0.99.  The number could fall from here, or continue rising.  I'll overweight a return to below 8, but with a bigger hedge.
Remember when a rather large percentage of people around the world thought Americans were generally pretty smart?
Oops!  We just popped up to 6 states (MI, ID, SD, AK, RI, NJ).  I believe it will fall again by March 31, but I'll increase my hedge.
The rate of decrease is slowing approaching zero. This means that infection rate is increasing.

Currently 8 states above an infection rate of 1.  Coupling this data with @Lance-Lawson 's article, it appears the trajectory will dip below 7. https://www.statista.com/statistics/1119412/covid-19-transmission-rate-us-by-state/

On covidactnow.org , the suggested rate is currently 7 [1]. Rapid introduction of the vaccine initiated by the Trump administration under Project Warp Speed and continued under the Biden Administration has played a heavy role in decreased transmission rates, which has depressed the prediction present on covidactnow.org. Infection rates continue to decline in tandem with the increased availability of the vaccine. For these reasons, I strongly suspect that covidactnow.org's prediction is accurate and that the situation will only improve as millions of vaccines are given each week, leading to decreased infection rates. [1] https://covidactnow.org/?s=1633574

It is both interesting and disconcerting that the two states (ND & SD) that had the most total confirmed per capita infections -- about 13% -- now have the highest infection rates.  It puts to rest the argument that the undetected infection rate is 6.5 times the confirmed rate.  That would put total infections at 85% of the population, which one would expect to provide herd immunity. The average infection rate for the 50 states + DC has increased from 0.82 to 0.87 over just the past three days.  Is this due to the storm, virus mutations, or loosening of COVID restrictions?  I think it's more of the latter, but I really don't know.  Three states have Rt values > 1.00 (ND, SD & WY), and AK is at 0.99.  The infection rates are low, but the trend is not good.  And there is over one month left for this question. I'll continue to overweight "7 or fewer," but I'll hedge a bit more, and check the data every day.
Only two states are currently on this list and vaccine distribution indicates that the rate will only continue to drop.
Less than 8 for several weeks, and the epidemic is stable/starting to rise slightly
At the moment, no state has an infection rate above 1%. With trends of daily cases falling and inoculation rates slowly rising, I think that it is highly unlikely that 7 states will rise above 1%.

The decline in cases has been faster than I expected, and I think there's a good chance we hit the low point in cases within the next month. After that it's anyone's guess what could happen, and a small bump in cases around the end of the question could increase the infection rates. Based on that coming down 10 on 7 or less and spreading probabilities a bit.

This is what one gets for not checking the numbers every day, I suppose.  Several states starting to move up the league tables on this metric; still think there won't be eight by March, but I reckon I'll have to give up some nap time to keep an eye on it.

The third (4th?)wave wil happen), + 29 will happen, don’t know when. 31/03 seems time enough.... coul be later though... Lot of people I follow giving +90 to ´7 or fewer’ , don’t know why, makes me think I’m thinking wrong here...

There are not currently any states with a 1.0 infection rate or higher.  With cases decreasing and more individuals being vaccinated, it seems incredibly unlikely that 8 states or more will have an infection rate of 1.0 or above at the end of March.
Only one state currently has an infection rate of 1.0 or greater for COVID-19.

Current number is zero, but infection rate is tricky, even a minor upward wave in daily cases around that time could easily put quite a few states over 1.0. That said I'm optimistic on the effects of the vaccines and we've had a massive number of cases so it does seem like there's potentially a long way to drop. The spread of variants such as UK and South Africa variants are probably the biggest risk right now I would guess.

Today: 0
Rapid decrease. Variants have no impact
Shifting some of the last bracket toward the center to account for independence in outcomes.
This pandemic has a three year cycle like most previous ones with the fast deployment of vaccinations reducing it by six months to a year. Hence  no reduction in spread short term.
Between vaccines and a Democrat Administration and Congress, the virus will be controlled.
I expect the new variants to increase transmission rate.

I truly do not understand the math.  How does one calculate the rate when, apparently, some 40 % (or some number) are asymptomatic.  Thus, responses are  pure guesses.  Ah so'; like herd immunity there is the herd guess.

It seems that the typical path for virus spread is exponential increase, followed by exponential decay. Therefore, Rt measures tend to auto-correlated, starting much above 1.0, decreasing toward 1.0 at the daily case peak, then decreasing further from there. If the Rt measure uses any smoothing factors, it shouldn't increase without some change in the population.  However, as the cases get very low, the Rt will increase back toward 1.0. For example, if 100 people give the virus to 90 others, that's a 0.9 Rt. But, if there is only 1 case and that person give the virus to 2 people, that's an Rt of 2.0 (in very simplified terms). This fact provides an alternative way for a state to have an Rt slightly above 1.0 on March 31. That is, a state could be so successful over the next 8 weeks that a small outbreak could increase the value. The other way that it could happen is that a state's population could change its behavior in Mid-March, increasing the contacts between infected and susceptible hosts. This might include the return to large gatherings in the Spring.  While the general trend over the next two months should be downward (especially as more people become immune or spend more time outside), it seems like there are reasonable odds that the trend will flatten or reverse by the end of March (although at much lower daily case counts than November). All of this indicates that zero states is a realistic outcome. But, 50 states is also plausible.

COVID case numbers are highly politicized as was seen this year during the run up to the US Presidential Election.  States with severe lockdown orders like New York, CA, and DC have reduced them significantly (re-opening restaurants for example) all the while the supposed cases are increasing in these areas, which given their prior logic would indicate their lockdown policy should be tightened, not reduced. Therefore, the metric for positive cases is unlikely to reach 1.0 in any US state because the political narrative will be geared towards showing success against the disease.  Not to mention, the vaccine is well under way with nearly a million doses being distributed daily.
With two more months of vaccinations it seems highly unlikely that infection rates will not continue to  drop

The challenge here is that Rt changes as conditions change. For example, a very strong control effort in February can push Rt down going into March. But, the low infection rate sets a low bar from which to grow. The question isn't whether things are better or worse on March 31 vs. today. It's whether they are better or worse than March 30. With this in mind, there is incredible uncertainty here. Therefore, I'm spreading the probabilities wide for now.
Betting on no significant bounce in the next two months.

According to covidactnow the average Rt for the 50 states + DC has fallen to 0.892.  Rt is down, but will it stay down through February?  Based on the crowd forecast the answer is probably, but not definitively.  That sounds about right, IMO.

The open questions are what percentage of people will get the vaccine this is going to be the next great emergency in the US I was only 50% -60 %of the people Will sign up to get the vaccine. The next questions are efficacy against variations. The next question is liability and side effects of the vaccine.   The threshold date is too late in the threshold number is too high

There is one important detail that should not be concealed and about which there needs to be a massive education effort among all those who receive their vaccine (which I doubt will happen in the U.S. in a sufficient manner):
with all good that a vaccine does on an individual level, as it prevents those inoculated from having a severe infection (known under the name COVID-19) and from being admitted to a hospital, it is so far not known how far a vaccine protects from being infected at all, and from being infectious to others (transmission of the virus into the wider society). The more people get vaccinated and the more these deviate from the regular recommendations of hygiene and safety measures (mask-wearing in particular), the more avoidable transmission from vaccinated individuals to others will be observed as long as not more than, say, 40% of the total population has received at least one shot (and natural immunization by an overcome infection is included), which could spark a fourth surge of the virus across the U.S. in late February 2021 and bring up the r(t) figures up in several states again which see a currently low r(t) figure due to a recent massive drop in infections. Lately, Prof Jonathan Van-Tam, England's deputy chief medical officer, explained the context to warn the British public of fading safety precautions after vaccination:
https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-55784199

There currently are 4 states with an infection rate equal to or greater than 1.0.  Although, the graphs for coronavirus are exponential with transfer rates, this question takes a snapsnot on March 31. 2021.  There are 21M COVID vaccines that have been administered with about 1M occurring each day.  By March 31st, about 100M vaccines will be administered, which totals 50M people.  There are 255M adults in the United States, so roughly 20% of the population will have received a vaccine.  These numbers assume only two vaccines; if the Johnson & Johnson vaccine is approved and distributed within a few weeks, even more individuals will be vaccinated.  Additionally, the infection rate for the country is declining as vaccine administration increases based upon the graph below:
https://covid19-projections.com/infections/us
Currently there are 13 with a handful close.  Trend/bias appears downward.  Upward bias potentially from vaccine uncertainty and new variations
We're down to 4.  I believe it will go down further, maybe even to zero.  But it could increase in February if the B117 mutation becomes more prevalent.

today:4 Factors that may decrease this number in the coming weeks :
- Vaccines (but will take longer to take effect);
- new social distancing measures (but none planned in advance). Factors that may increase this number:
- variants (uncertainty about the magnitude of their impact)

Expecting major/rapid drop in cases to happen in February to March beginning. Thereafter, it will be more gradual drop in cases with a possibility of flat to slightly increasing trend. Which will put 20-27 states in Rt above 1.0

UK variant

General assumptions  There is 50 states + 1 (DC). 
RT is a variation about the number of case, hospitalization and death for a period.  Until there will not be great borders restrictions, or a great number of people with vaccine Covid -19  will be out of control.  
For now, There is a lot plane in the USA sky ( https://www.flightradar24.com/40.44,-73.83/9)  In two months, USA wont be in control (RT > = < 1). Some states will be higher, other lower than  the previous period. Alaska and Hawaii should be in absolute control so 51 - 2 = 49 , than 24,5 should be the number.
7 now: https://covidactnow.org/?s=1538484 Remember this nightmare? Yep, still gonna use it: https://rt.live/

The number is currently 7 on the covidactnow.org website that will determine the outcome of the question, while Rt.live is showing 10.  Looking at the error bands for the data on Rt.live, the answer could be anything between 0 and 49.  As we learned from previous questions, Rt can be quite volatile, at least as tracked by Rt.live.  I haven't been watching Rt on covidactnow, so if any of you have been following that data please comment. I also note that the two sources of Rt data differ greatly -- Rt for Vermont is 1.17 on Rt.live but only 1.02 on covidactnow.org.  For Hawaii the numbers are 1.14 and 0.89.  So Hawaii either has rapidly increasing new infections, or rapidly falling infections.  Take your pick.  This question uses the lower figures from covidactnow. I'll start with a forecast favoring the lower brackets.  So far the vaccine projections at https://covid19-projections.com/path-to-herd-immunity/ have held up.  If this continues the rate of new infections will be ~70% lower by March 31.  But fewer new infections does not mean lower Rt.  Rt reflects the rate of change of new infections, not the absolute level.  If new infections fall a lot but then bounce up in late March the average Rt should show an increase in the number of states with Rt > 0.99.  So I won't go all in for "7 or fewer."
Am I missing something here? We have passed the peak. This is following the flu season curve. We are already down to 7 states and falling. We were at 36 States 5 days ago.

I'm favoring the lower end, I'm assuming with vaccine rollout and whatever herd immunity came from this last wave we'll see a steady decline, which I believe would translate to RT numbers below 1.0. I'm leaving plenty of uncertainty because it's possible for it to be a wavy decline too, or maybe it doesn't decline much and just fluctuates up and down. If March 31 happens to be on an upward trend, even if cases are half what they are now, it's possible for RT numbers to be higher than 1.0 in many states.
